ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about different types of songs and structures in musicals, and got a lot of practice writing lyrics in these different styles. I received excellent feedback on how to improve my lyrics, which allowed me to make great progress in my lyric writing skills.
I had never taken a musical writing course prior to this class and I absolutely loved it. I learned all about proper techniques of writing songs and also what it takes to become a lyricist.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Time in class is extremely well spent. I thought that spending a whole class focusing on one type of song was particularly useful, and it might be worth spending a couple more classes to go over all the standard types of songs that appear in musical. It was a great experience to talk with and get feedback from the various distinguished guests that came to the classes.
This course was very well done. I didnt experience any weaknesses with it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would strongly recommend this class to anyone with an interest in musical theater. Classes are extremely enjoyable and well taught, and the assignments dont take too much time and are a lot of fun to do. Micheal Korie is truly an expert, and he does a great job helping students of all levels improve.
Definitely. It is something that you wont know you like until you try the class.
